id="keys0001" class="keywords-section"><h2 class="section-title u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">Keywords</h2><div id="key0001" class="keyword"><span id="cetext0002">Manganese-based layered oxides</span></div><div id="key0002" class="keyword"><span id="cetext0003">Synergetic effect</span></div><div id="key0003" class="keyword"><span id="cetext0004">Sodium-ion batteries</span></div><div id="key0004" class="keyword"><span id="cetext0005">Phase transition retardant</span></div><div id="key0005" class="keyword"><span id="cetext0006">Kinetics enhancement</span></div></div></div><div class="Body u-font-serif" id="body"><div><section id="sec0001"><h2 id="cesectitle0006" class="u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">1. Introduction</h2><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="para0006"><span>Sodium-ion batteries (SIBs) have been considered as alternative supplements for Li-ion batteries (LIBs) owing to the source abundance and cost advantage of <a href="/topics/chemistry/sodium" title="Learn more about sodium from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">sodium</a> compared to lithium </span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0001" name="bbib0001" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0001"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[1]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0002" name="bbib0002" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0002"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[2]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0003" name="bbib0003" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0003"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[3]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0004" name="bbib0004" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0004"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[4]</span></span></a><span><span>. In SIBs, <a href="/topics/materials-science/cathode-material" title="Learn more about cathode materials from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">cathode materials</a> primarily dominate the cost and </span><a href="/topics/materials-science/energy-density" title="Learn more about energy density from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">energy density</a>, which is a substantial factor in achieving large-scale commercial applications [</span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0005" name="bbib0005" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0005"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">5</span></span></a>,<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0006" name="bbib0006" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0006"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">6</span></span></a><span>]. Among various cathode materials, manganese-based layered <a href="/topics/materials-science/oxide-compound" title="Learn more about oxide from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">oxide</a> (Na</span><sub>x</sub>MnO<sub>2</sub>, 0 &lt; <em>x</em> ≤ 1) cathodes are appropriate for rechargeable SIBs due to large specific capacity, sustainability, and simple manufacture <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0007" name="bbib0007" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0007"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[7]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0008" name="bbib0008" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0008"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[8]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0009" name="bbib0009" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0009"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[9]</span></span></a>. These Na<sub>x</sub>MnO<sub>2</sub><span> compounds can be classified into P- and O- types based on the alignment of oxygen coordinated with <a href="/topics/materials-science/sodium-ion" title="Learn more about sodium ions from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">sodium ions</a><span> and the stacking sequence of transition <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/metal-ion" title="Learn more about metal ions from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">metal ions</a> </span></span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0010" name="bbib0010" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0010"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[10]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0011" name="bbib0011" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0011"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[11]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0012" name="bbib0012" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0012"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[12]</span></span></a>. In general, the P2-type Na<sub>x</sub>MnO<sub>2</sub> possesses notable feature with fewer phase transitions, enhanced Na<sup>+</sup> mobility, and higher rate capability compared to the O3-type <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0013" name="bbib0013" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0013"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[13]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0014" name="bbib0014" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0014"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[14]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0015" name="bbib0015" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0015"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[15]</span></span></a>. P’2 Na<sub>x</sub>MnO<sub>2</sub>, a distorted phase of P2 phase, not only possesses these advantages but also displays larger capacity and no Mn vacancies due to the presence of more Mn<sup>3+</sup> ions <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0016" name="bbib0016" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0016"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[16]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0017" name="bbib0017" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0017"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[17]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0018" name="bbib0018" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0018"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[18]</span></span></a>. However, it is still hindered by irreversible structural transformations during Na<sup>+</sup> (de)intercalation [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0019" name="bbib0019" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0019"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">19</span></span></a>,<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0020" name="bbib0020" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0020"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">20</span></span></a>]. The phase evolution causes sustained capacity decay and large volume change associated with microcracks, which continuously consumes electrolyte and forms overgrowth cathode-electrolyte interface (CEI), thus leading to sluggish kinetics with obstruction of electron/ion transport and inadequate practical performance [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0021" name="bbib0021" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0021"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">21</span></span></a>,<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0022" name="bbib0022" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0022"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">22</span></span></a>].</div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="para0007">Achieving high capacity and prolonged cycle durability are both crucial factors in the development of high-performance P’2 Na<sub>x</sub>MnO<sub>2</sub> cathode materials. Various approaches have been explored, including complex surface or morphology technologies and composite structure designs. However, the simple method of cation doping has proven to be highly effective in extending the stability range and enhancing Na<sup>+</sup> diffusion kinetics [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0023" name="bbib0023" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0023"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">23</span></span></a>,<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0024" name="bbib0024" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0024"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">24</span></span></a>]. The inactive Mg<sup>2+</sup><span> <a href="/topics/materials-science/doping-additives" title="Learn more about dopant from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">dopant</a> in transition metal layer serves to raise the valence of Mn, thereby reducing the Mn</span><sup>3+</sup> Jahn-Teller (J-T) active centers, in turn alleviating the Mn−O bond anisotropic alteration and delaying the phase transition process at the end-of-discharge [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0025" name="bbib0025" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0025"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">25</span></span></a>,<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0026" name="bbib0026" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0026"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">26</span></span></a>]. Additionally, introducing Mg<sup>2+</sup> can disrupt the Mn<sup>3+</sup>/<sup>4+</sup> ordering and Na<sup>+</sup>/vacancy arrangements, resulting in smoother charge-discharge curves and accelerated Na<sup>+</sup> conduction [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0025" name="bbib0025" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0025"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">25</span></span></a>,<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0027" name="bbib0027" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0027"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">27</span></span></a>,<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0028" name="bbib0028" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0028"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">28</span></span></a>]. Unfortunately, the doping electrochemical inactive metals will always inevitably result in a decrease in capacity [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0029" name="bbib0029" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0029"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">29</span></span></a>,<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0030" name="bbib0030" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0030"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">30</span></span></a>]. However, the F<sup>−</sup> anion dopant offers a partial compensation for the capacity losses caused by Mg doping. It also leads to a weaker Na-F interaction, which facilitates easier Na<sup>+</sup> diffusion by reducing the negative charge, as discovered in our previous study <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0031" name="bbib0031" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0031"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[31]</span></span></a>. In addition, strong TM-F bonds generated help to restrain the shearing of the [MnO<sub>6</sub><span>] layer at high voltage region, thanks to the strong <a href="/topics/chemistry/electronegativity" title="Learn more about electronegativity from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">electronegativity</a> of F</span><sup>−</sup><span> making for more reversible Na storage behavior and long-term <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/structural-stability" title="Learn more about structural stability from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">structural stability</a> [</span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0032" name="bbib0032" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0032"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">32</span></span></a>,<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0033" name="bbib0033" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0033"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">33</span></span></a><span>]. Inspired by these considerations, the combination of cationic and anionic dopants allows for fully utilization of their advantages, leading to superior <a href="/topics/materials-science/sodium" title="Learn more about sodium from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">sodium</a> storage performance while maintaining high specific capacity. Although some research has been conducted on cation and anion co-doping, further improvements are still required to enhance sodium storage behavior and a more comprehensive understanding of the relative roles of cations and anions in bulk crystal structure is needed.</span></div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="para0008">Herein, we synthesized a series of P’2-type Mn-based layered cathode materials to explore the synergistic effect of cation and anion co-doping, including Na<sub>0.65</sub>MnO<sub>2</sub> (NMO), Na<sub>0.64</sub>Mn<sub>0.96</sub>Mg<sub>0.04</sub>O<sub>1.92</sub>F<sub>0.08</sub> (NMMOF), Na<sub>0.67</sub>Mn<sub>0.96</sub>Mg<sub>0.04</sub>O<sub>2</sub> (NMMO) and Na<sub>0.66</sub>MnO<sub>1.92</sub>F<sub>0.08</sub> (NMOF). In detail, Mg<sup>2+</sup> dopant contributes to suppressing the metastable intermediates caused by Na<sup>+</sup>/vacancy rearrangement and Mn-O anisotropic changes. Meanwhile, the F<sup>−</sup><span> dopant facilitate the acceleration of <a href="/topics/chemistry/electrochemical-reaction" title="Learn more about electrochemical reaction from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">electrochemical reaction</a> and Na</span><sup>+</sup> diffusion kinetics, thereby reducing electrochemical impedance and alleviated multiphase transformation at deeply charged state due to its lower negative charge than O<sup>2−</sup>. Benefitting from the synergistic co-doping strategy, the modified materials deliver high specific capacity, extended long cycle life, alleviated voltage decay and impressive rate capability, making them a promising candidate for large-scale energy storage systems.</div></section><section id="sec0002"><h2 id="cesectitle0007" class="u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">2. Material and methods</h2><section id="sec0003"><h3 id="cesectitle0008" class="u-h4 u-margin-m-top u-margin-xs-bottom">2.1. Material preparation</h3><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="para0009">The NMMOF was synthesized via a facile and conventional solid-state approach. Ball-milling was conducted with acetone for 4 h at 400 rpm with stoichiometric amounts of Na<sub>2</sub>CO<sub>3</sub> (Aladdin, 99.5 %)<sub>,</sub> Mn<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub> (Aladdin, 98.0 %) and MgF<sub>2</sub> (Aladdin, 99 %). To compensate for the weight loss at high temperatures, an additional molar excess of 5 % Na<sub>2</sub>CO<sub>3</sub><span> was provided. The precursors were vacuum dried at 80 °C for 10 h and pressed into pellets. Following that, the pellets were calcined at 900 °C for 12 h in the Muffle furnace earlier being quenched to <a href="/topics/chemistry/ambient-reaction-temperature" title="Learn more about room temperature from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">room temperature</a><span><span>. Finally, all of the prepared products were then promptly transformed into <a href="/topics/chemistry/glovebox-technique" title="Learn more about glovebox from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">glovebox</a> for storage. The synthesis procedures of NMMO and NMOF were similar, except for the addition of </span><a href="/topics/materials-science/magnesium-oxide" title="Learn more about MgO from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">MgO</a> (Aladdin, 98.0 %) or NaF (Aladdin, 98.0 %) instead of MgF</span></span><sub>2</sub>, respectively. Additionally, the NMO was obtained by solid-state approach utilizing Na<sub>2</sub>CO<sub>3</sub> and Mn<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub>.</div></section><section id="sec0004"><h3 id="cesectitle0009" class="u-h4 u-margin-m-top u-margin-xs-bottom">2.2. Structure characterization</h3><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="para0010"><span><span><span>The crystallization information and <a href="/topics/chemistry/phase-composition" title="Learn more about phase composition from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">phase composition</a><span> of the <a href="/topics/materials-science/cathode-material" title="Learn more about cathode materials from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">cathode materials</a> were investigated by powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) analysis, using Rigaku SmartLab with Cu Kα radiation. The actual chemical concentration of Na, Mg, and Mn was analyzed by </span></span><a href="/topics/chemistry/inductively-coupled-plasma" title="Learn more about inductively coupled plasma from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">inductively coupled plasma</a> </span><a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/optical-emission-spectroscopy" title="Learn more about optical emission spectroscopy from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">optical emission spectroscopy</a> (ICP-OES, Aglient 5110). </span><sup>19</sup><span>F <a href="/topics/chemistry/solid-state-nuclear-magnetic-resonance" title="Learn more about solid state nuclear magnetic resonance from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">solid state nuclear magnetic resonance</a><span> (ssNMR) was carried out at 9.4 T using a Bruker 400 M spectrometer. Scanning electron microscopy (SEM) was conducted on a JSM-7900F (JEOL) microscope to characterize morphology and microstructure of the prepared materials. High-resolution transmission <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/electron-microscope" title="Learn more about electron microscope from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">electron microscope</a> (HRTEM) images were acquired by a Talos F200X G2 (FEI, AEMC). And energy dispersive X-ray spectrometer (EDS) equipped on TEM was used to obtain elements distribution of the samples. The elements valence states of the samples were performed on X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS, ThermoFisher, Thermo Scientific K-Alpha).</span></span></div></section><section id="sec0005"><h3 id="cesectitle0010" class="u-h4 u-margin-m-top u-margin-xs-bottom">2.3. Electrochemistry measurements</h3><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="para0011"><span><span><a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/electrochemical-performance" title="Learn more about Electrochemical performances from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">Electrochemical performances</a> of samples were carried out via employing a stainless-steel coin cell (CR2032) and the entire operation was conducted inside an Ar-filled glovebox with water and oxygen levels below 0.01 ppm. The cathode electrodes were made by spreading an 8:1:1 (weight ratio) slurry of active material, carbon black and </span><a href="/topics/chemistry/polyvinylidene-fluoride" title="Learn more about polyvinylidene fluoride from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">polyvinylidene fluoride</a> (PVDF) over Al foil. The loading mass of active cathode material was ∼2.0 mg cm</span><sup>−2</sup><span>.The electrodes were dried at 100 °C for 8 h to evaporate N-methyl-2-pyrrolidone (NMP) solvent before being cut into disks with diameter of 10 mm. Furthermore, <a href="/topics/chemistry/glass-fiber" title="Learn more about glass fiber from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">glass fiber</a> acted as separator, and the electrolyte was 1 M NaPF</span><sub>6</sub><span> in <a href="/topics/chemistry/propene" title="Learn more about propylene from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">propylene</a> carbonate (PC) with 2 % fluoroethylene carbonate (FEC).</span></div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="para0012"><span>The Land <a href="/topics/chemistry/battery-electrochemical-energy-engineering" title="Learn more about battery from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">battery</a> systems were used to perform the galvanostatic charge-discharge (GCD) measurement in 2.0–4.0 V (vs. Na/Na</span><sup>+</sup>) at different currents (10–1000 mA g<sup>–1</sup><span>). CHI660B workstation (CHI Instruments, Shanghai, China) was utilized to carry out the <a href="/topics/materials-science/cyclic-voltammetry" title="Learn more about Cyclic voltammetry from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">Cyclic voltammetry</a><span> (CV) measurement and <a href="/topics/materials-science/dielectric-spectroscopy" title="Learn more about Electrochemical impedance spectroscopy from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">Electrochemical impedance spectroscopy</a> (EIS). The CV curves were obtained at 0.1 mV s</span></span><sup>–1</sup> within 2.0 - 4.0 V (vs. Na/Na<sup>+</sup><span>), and EIS measurement was carried out within 100 kHz - 50 mHz. The <a href="/topics/chemistry/diffusion-coefficient" title="Learn more about diffusion coefficient from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">diffusion coefficient</a> of Na</span><sup>+</sup> (D<sub>Na</sub><sup>+</sup><span>) was measured by applying the repeated current pulses for 30 min at a <a href="/topics/chemistry/current-density" title="Learn more about current density from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">current density</a> of 20 mA g</span><sup>–1</sup><span> followed by relaxation for 6 h via Galvanostatic Intermittent <a href="/topics/chemistry/titration" title="Learn more about Titration from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">Titration</a> Technique (GITT).</span></div></section><section id="sec0006"><h3 id="cesectitle0011" class="u-h4 u-margin-m-top u-margin-xs-bottom">2.4. Density functional theory (DFT) calculations</h3><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="para0013">Spin-polarized calculations were performed via the Vienna Ab-initio Simulation Package (VASP 6.1) [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0034" name="bbib0034" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0034"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">34</span></span></a>,<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0035" name="bbib0035" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0035"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">35</span></span></a>] with the project augmented wave (PAW) pseudopetentials method [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0036" name="bbib0036" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0036"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">36</span></span></a>,<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0037" name="bbib0037" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0037"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">37</span></span></a><span>]. All electronic structures were calculated using the <a href="/topics/chemistry/generalized-gradient-approximation" title="Learn more about generalized gradient approximation from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">generalized gradient approximation</a> (GGA) with the Perdew-Burke-Ernzerhof (PBE) functional </span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0034" name="bbib0034" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0034"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[34]</span></span></a>. The convergence criterion for energy and force was set to 10<sup>−5</sup><span> eV and 0.02 eV/Å, respectively. The <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/density-functional-theory" title="Learn more about DFT from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">DFT</a> + U method with </span><em>U</em> = 3.9 eV was used to describe the strong correlation for Mn 3d electrons. To determine potential configurations for the synthesized materials, a total of 20 possible arrangements based on the stoichiometric ratios were randomly generated using the Atomic Simulation Environment (ASE) tool <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0038" name="bbib0038" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0038"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[38]</span></span></a><span>. The most stable configurations were selected and further calculated with DFT. The total energy was converged to less than 1 meV/atom using a plane wave cutoff energy of 500 eV. For geometry optimization, we employed a 4 × 3 × 3 Monkhorst–Pack k-point mesh, while an 8 × 6 × 6 Monkhorst–Pack k-point mesh was utilized for calculating <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/density-of-states" title="Learn more about densities of states from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">densities of states</a>.</span></div></section></section><section id="sec0007"><h2 id="cesectitle0012" class="u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">3. Results and discussion</h2><section id="sec0008"><h3 id="cesectitle0013" class="u-h4 u-margin-m-top u-margin-xs-bottom">3.1. Structural characterization</h3><div class="u-margin-s-bottom"><div id="para0014">The NMO, NMMOF, NMMO, and NMOF were successfully synthesized as evidenced by the absence of any visible impurity peak in X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns. In <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig0001" name="bfig0001" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig0001"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 1</span></span></a>a and b and Fig. S1a and b, all of the diffraction peaks can be accurately assigned to P’2-type structure with a <span><em><a href="/topics/chemistry/cmcm" title="Learn more about cmcm from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">cmcm</a></em></span> space group [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0039" name="bbib0039" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0039"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">39</span></span></a>,<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0040" name="bbib0040" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0040"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">40</span></span></a><span>]. The actual chemical concentrations of all the cathode compounds were determined using ICP-OES for refinement, and the results (Table S1) closely matched the theoretical values. The fluorine distribution within NMMOF was revealed by <a href="/topics/chemistry/solid-state-nuclear-magnetic-resonance" title="Learn more about ssNMR from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">ssNMR</a> as shown in Fig. S2, and the results demonstrate the successful incorporation of fluorine into the bulk phase rather than its deposition as NaF on the surface. Due to the strong paramagnetic interaction between </span><sup>19</sup>F nuclei and the unpaired d electrons of the Mn ions, no discernible <sup>19</sup>F signals are observed in NMMOF material [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0041" name="bbib0041" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0041"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">41</span></span></a>,<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0042" name="bbib0042" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0042"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">42</span></span></a>]. During the transition from NMO to NMMOF, Mn octahedral sites are preferred by Mg whereas F resides in O sites, and the detailed parameters are listed in Tables S2–S5. The distortion degree (δ) is calculated following previous study <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0018" name="bbib0018" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0018"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[18]</span></span></a>. Compared with NMO having distortion degree of 7.00 %, NMMOF exhibits lower distortion degree of 5.92 %, while NMMO and NMOF have distortion degrees of 6.38 % and 7.07 % respectively. This improvement is attributed to the decrease in Mn<sup>3+</sup><span>, which is responsible for J-T distortion, revealed by the shift to higher binding energy in <a href="/topics/materials-science/x-ray-photoelectron-spectroscopy" title="Learn more about XPS from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">XPS</a> spectra presented in Fig. S3. Meanwhile, NMMOF has enlarged Na</span><sup>+</sup> layer spacing and contracted [MnO<sub>6</sub>] layer spacing in sharp contrast to NMO (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig0001" name="bfig0001" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig0001"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 1</span></span></a>c). And the distance of Na<sup>+</sup> layer and [MnO<sub>6</sub>] layer in NMMO is confirmed as 3.59 Å and 2.01 Å separately, as well as 3.56 Å and 2.04 Å in NMOF (Fig. S1c and d). It reveals that more Mn<sup>4+</sup><span> with stronger <a href="/topics/chemistry/electronegativity" title="Learn more about electronegativity from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">electronegativity</a> and smaller ionic radius in structure leads to the shrinkage of [MnO</span><sub>6</sub>] layer and expansion of Na<sup>+</sup><span> layer via more intensive <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/electrostatics" title="Learn more about electrostatic from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">electrostatic</a> attraction with adjacent oxygen. Thus, incorporating Mg and F into the framework enables the generation of a more stable structure with larger Na layer distance, which contributes to better performance.</span></div><figure class="figure text-xs" id="fig0001"><span><img src="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S2405829724001302-gr1.jpg" height="565" alt="Fig 1" aria-describedby="cap0001"><ol class="u-margin-s-bottom"><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S2405829724001302-gr1_lrg.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download high-res image (1MB)"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download high-res image (1MB)</span></span></span></a></li><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S2405829724001302-gr1.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download full-size image"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download full-size image</span></span></span></a></li></ol></span><span class="captions text-s"><span id="cap0001"><p id="spara001"><span class="label">Fig. 1</span>. <span>Rietveld refined <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/diffraction-pattern" title="Learn more about XRD patterns from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">XRD patterns</a> of a) NMO and b) NMMOF. c) Schematic illustration of the structural transition from NMO to NMMOF. d-e) SEM images, f) HRTEM image and g) </span><a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/electron-diffraction" title="Learn more about SAED from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">SAED</a> pattern of NMMOF.</p></span></span></figure></div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="para0015">All of the as-prepared samples display smooth plate-like appearance in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig0001" name="bfig0001" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig0001"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 1</span></span></a><span>d and e and S4, indicating that the presence of Mg and F does not affect the samples’ morphology. <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/electron-microscope" title="Learn more about HRTEM from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">HRTEM</a> analysis in </span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig0001" name="bfig0001" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig0001"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 1</span></span></a>f and S5a–c reveals that the distance of adjacent [MnO<sub>6</sub><span>] slabs corresponds to (002) planes of P’2-type structure, in accordance with the XRD refinement results. The selected area <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/electron-diffraction" title="Learn more about electron diffraction from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">electron diffraction</a> (SAED) results presented in </span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig0001" name="bfig0001" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig0001"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 1</span></span></a><span>g and S5d confirm that as-prepared samples possess the <a href="/topics/chemistry/orthorhombic-space-group" title="Learn more about orthorhombic crystal structure from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">orthorhombic crystal structure</a>, coinciding with the P’2 phase. Moreover, energy-dispersive spectroscopy (EDS) mappings in Fig. S6 reveal a homogenous distribution of various elements within the bulk structure.</span></div></section><section id="sec0009"><h3 id="cesectitle0014" class="u-h4 u-margin-m-top u-margin-xs-bottom">3.2. Electrochemical performance</h3><div class="u-margin-s-bottom"><div id="para0016">The GCD tests were tested within 2.0–4.0 V (vs. Na/Na<sup>+</sup>) at 20 mA g<sup>–1</sup>. From the first three cycles capacity-voltage profiles in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig0002" name="bfig0002" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig0002"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 2</span></span></a>a, NMO can deliver a discharge specific capacity of 213.18 mAh g<sup>–1</sup> (0.81 Na<sup>+</sup> insertion per formula), while the specific capacity decreased rapidly. The multiple voltage plateaus in the NMO capacity-voltage profiles are attributed to the Na<sup>+</sup>/vacancy ordering and phase transition processes, which will be discussed later. In contrast, NMMOF processes smoother and more reversible capacity-voltage profiles with a discharge specific capacity of 200.88 mAh g<sup>–1</sup> (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig0002" name="bfig0002" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig0002"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 2</span></span></a>b), indicating that each formula unit incorporates 0.75 Na<sup>+</sup> into the framework. The slightly reduced discharge specific capacity in NMMOF is due to the more Mn<sup>4+</sup> in the structure caused by inactive Mg<sup>2+</sup><span> <a href="/topics/materials-science/doping-additives" title="Learn more about dopant from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">dopant</a> as indicated by XPS results. As for the respective influence of Mg and F dopants, Mg dopant clearly smoothens the charge-discharge curves (Fig. S7a and b), whereas no such effect is observed with F dopant exhibiting multiple voltage plateaus. However, it is evident that the charge-discharge curves overlap well in the initial three cycles following Mg or F induction, indicating the enhanced reversibility. Despite causing a slight capacity decline for NMMO, the inactive Mg dopant significantly suppresses the detrimental Na</span><sup>+</sup>/vacancy ordering rearrangement.</div><figure class="figure text-xs" id="fig0002"><span><img src="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S2405829724001302-gr2.jpg" height="640" alt="Fig 2" aria-describedby="cap0002"><ol class="u-margin-s-bottom"><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S2405829724001302-gr2_lrg.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download high-res image (959KB)"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download high-res image (959KB)</span></span></span></a></li><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S2405829724001302-gr2.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download full-size image"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download full-size image</span></span></span></a></li></ol></span><span class="captions text-s"><span id="cap0002"><p id="spara002"><span class="label">Fig. 2</span>. Electrochemical performance of as-prepared samples: a) the initial three cycles GCD curves of NMO, b) the initial three cycles GCD curves of NMMOF, c) EIS comparison of NMO, NMMOF, NMMO, and NMOF, d) cycling stability collected on NMO and NMMOF at 1000 mA g<sup>–1</sup>, e) rate capability of NMO, NMMOF, NMMO, and NMOF, f) the D<sub>Na</sub><sup>+</sup> collected on NMO and NMMOF, g) CV curves at different scan rates for NMMOF, h) linear relationship of log <em>i</em> and log <em>v</em> of Peak 1 and Peak 2 for NMMOF.</p></span></span></figure></div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="para0017"><span>The <a href="/topics/materials-science/dielectric-spectroscopy" title="Learn more about EIS from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">EIS</a> comparison in </span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig0002" name="bfig0002" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig0002"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 2</span></span></a>c shows that synergistically co-doping of Mg and F significantly enhances charge transfer capabilities, resulting in a remarkable reduction in resistance. The cycling performance at 100 mA g<sup>–1</sup> in Fig. S8a manifests that the NMMOF exhibits considerable cycling stability with a capacity retention of 79.12 % after 200 cycles, while NMO only offers very limited capacity retention of 35.52 %. The NMMOF electrode, in particular, displays ultra-long stability of 81.23 % over 750 cycles at 1000 mA g<sup>–1</sup> while keeping high specific capacity. This performance surpasses that of NMO, which suffers from poor capacity retention of 6.57 % (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig0002" name="bfig0002" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig0002"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 2</span></span></a><span>d). Meanwhile, the Coulombic efficiency of NMO fluctuates greatly after 300 cycles, suggesting the structural deterioration and the onset of undesirable side reactions. In addition, the NMMOF shows higher average voltage and much more restrained voltage decay than NMO (Fig. S8b). Hence, the aforementioned results demonstrate that the co-doping strategy contributes to prolonged cycle life and superior <a href="/topics/chemistry/sodium" title="Learn more about sodium from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">sodium</a> storage properties. As displayed in </span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig0002" name="bfig0002" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig0002"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 2</span></span></a>e, the rate performance at currents ranging from 10 mA g<sup>–1</sup> to 1000 mA g<sup>–1</sup> provides further insights into the impact of Mg and F co-doping. The NMMOF electrode exhibits an impressive capacity of 120.26 mAh g<sup>–1</sup> at 1000 mA g<sup>–1</sup>, and the recovered capacity at 100 mA g<sup>–1</sup> after the rate test reaches approximately 94.69 % (163.44 mAh g<sup>–1</sup>) of the pristine value obtained (172.61 mAh g<sup>–1</sup>). Both NMMO and NMOF show acceptable capacity decline with increased rates, whereas NMO displays limited capacity at high rates.</div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="para0018">The charge transfer and Na<sup>+</sup><span><span> conductivity in the electrodes markedly improve with the Mg and F dopants, leading to enhanced kinetics as evidenced by the <a href="/topics/chemistry/dielectric-spectroscopy" title="Learn more about EIS from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">EIS</a> and </span><a href="/topics/chemistry/titration" title="Learn more about GITT from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">GITT</a> results (Fig. S9). From </span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig0002" name="bfig0002" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig0002"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 2</span></span></a><span>f, the Na <a href="/topics/chemistry/diffusion-coefficient" title="Learn more about diffusion coefficient from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">diffusion coefficient</a> (D</span><sub>Na</sub><sup>+</sup>) evidently increases from a range of 5.35 × 10<sup>−15</sup> ∼ 7.00 × 10<sup>−11</sup> cm<sup>2</sup> S<sup>−1</sup> to 1.74 × 10<sup>−13</sup> ∼ 1.60 × 10<sup>−10</sup> cm<sup>2</sup> S<sup>−1</sup>, indicating that NMMOF has faster Na<sup>+</sup><span><span> mobility and lower Na <a href="/topics/chemistry/diffusion-barrier" title="Learn more about diffusion barrier from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">diffusion barrier</a> compared to NMO. In the </span><a href="/topics/materials-science/cyclic-voltammetry" title="Learn more about CV from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">CV</a> measurements of NMMOF and NMO at different scan rates (0.1–0.8 mV s</span><sup>–1</sup>) shown in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig0002" name="bfig0002" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig0002"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 2</span></span></a>g and S10a, NMMOF also exhibits much smoother curves than that of NMO, congruent with the GCD testing in which the Na<sup>+</sup><span>/vacancy ordering gets weaker. The reaction kinetics to the charge <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/storage-process" title="Learn more about storage process from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">storage process</a> is calculated based upon the equation </span><em>i = av<sup>b</sup></em> (log <em>i</em> = log <em>a</em> + <em>b</em>log <em>v</em>). Specifically, the <em>i</em> stands for peak current, and <em>v</em> for scan rate. In <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig0002" name="bfig0002" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig0002"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 2</span></span></a>h and S10b, the log <em>i</em> vs. log <em>v</em> plots reveal the value of <em>b</em> in Peak 1 and Peak 2 of NMMOF and NMO separately, suggesting that the electrochemical process of NMMOF and NMO is controlled by a combination of diffusion-limited and capacitive behaviors. The specific contribution of pseudocapacitance is calculated based on the equation <em>i</em>= <em>k<sub>1</sub>v</em> + <em>k<sub>2</sub>v</em><sup>0.5</sup>, where <em>k</em><sub><em>1</em></sub><em>v</em> and <em>k<sub>2</sub>v</em><sup>0.5</sup> represent the capacitive and diffusion-limited currents [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0043" name="bbib0043" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0043"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">43</span></span></a>,<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0044" name="bbib0044" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0044"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">44</span></span></a>], respectively (Fig. S11). There is a larger capacitive contribution of Peak 1 and Peak 2 in NMMOF than that of NMO (Fig. S12), indicating a more stored charge and faster kinetics in NMMOF <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0045" name="bbib0045" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0045"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[45]</span></span></a>. As a consequence, NMMOF displays impressive rate performance due to expanded Na<sup>+</sup> layer spacing derived fast diffusion capability.</div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom"><div id="para0019">XRD and HRTEM were applied to investigate the underlying factors contributing to this discrepancy in electrode stability. The comparison of XRD patterns in Fig. S13 proves that NMMOF electrode can preserve structure integrity after cycling for 50 cycles at 100 mA g<sup>–1</sup>, whereas NMO has two distinct phases, indicating NMO undergoes unrecoverable structural evolution during repeated charging-discharging process. Meanwhile, unlike the NMO with mismatch and disorders depicted in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig0003" name="bfig0003" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig0003"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 3</span></span></a>b, the crystal structure of NMMOF maintains more intact (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig0003" name="bfig0003" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig0003"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 3</span></span></a>a). Notably, the CEI of NMMOF (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig0003" name="bfig0003" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig0003"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 3</span></span></a>c) is uniform and well maintained without apparent change after 50 cycles at 100 mA g<sup>–1</sup>, which is considered as a crucial factor for the markedly extended cycling performance. Conversely, uneven and overgrowth CEI film is formed on surface of NMO due to large volume change (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig0003" name="bfig0003" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig0003"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 3</span></span></a>d), which hinders ion transportation and leads to extra electrolyte consumption [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0046" name="bbib0046" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0046"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">46</span></span></a>,<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0047" name="bbib0047" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0047"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">47</span></span></a>]. The CEI components of NMMOF and NMO are explored utilizing XPS with various Ar<sup>+</sup> etching depth. The C-O and C<img src="https://sdfestaticassets-us-east-1.sciencedirectassets.com/shared-assets/55/entities/dbnd.gif" style="vertical-align: middle;" alt="double bond">O intensities in O 1 s spectra (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig0003" name="bfig0003" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig0003"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 3</span></span></a>e and f) of NMMOF are lower than those of NMO, indicating that the unstable and friable organic species diminish on NMMOF electrode surface [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0048" name="bbib0048" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0048"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">48</span></span></a>,<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0049" name="bbib0049" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0049"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">49</span></span></a>]. The similar phenomenon can be observed in C 1 s spectra (Fig. S14). Specifically, as shown in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig0003" name="bfig0003" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig0003"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 3</span></span></a>g and h, the NaF signal in F 1 s spectra of NMMOF is far higher compared to NMO under altered Ar<sup>+</sup> etching depth, suggesting a more stable and uniform CEI enriched with NaF. The NaF-enriched CEI on NMMOF facilitates easier Na<sup>+</sup> diffusion, reduces parasitic reactions and mitigates electrode cracking [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0050" name="bbib0050" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0050"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">50</span></span></a>,<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0051" name="bbib0051" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0051"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">51</span></span></a><span>]. The boosted interface stability endows NMMOF electrode with more robust framework, ultimately beneficial to an extended cycling life and improved kinetics. Thus, the combined effects of Mg and F synergistically enhance the electrochemical performance in terms of reversible charge-discharge processes, good <a href="/topics/materials-science/electrical-conductivity" title="Learn more about electrical conductivity from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">electrical conductivity</a>, enhanced rate capability, and outstanding cycling performance.</span></div><figure class="figure text-xs" id="fig0003"><span><img src="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S2405829724001302-gr3.jpg" height="471" alt="Fig 3" aria-describedby="cap0003"><ol class="u-margin-s-bottom"><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S2405829724001302-gr3_lrg.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download high-res image (1MB)"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download high-res image (1MB)</span></span></span></a></li><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S2405829724001302-gr3.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download full-size image"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download full-size image</span></span></span></a></li></ol></span><span class="captions text-s"><span id="cap0003"><p id="spara003"><span class="label">Fig. 3</span>. The characterization after 50 cycles at 100 mA g<sup>–1</sup>: The lattice fingers patterns of a) NMMOF and b) NMO. HRTEM images of CEI on c) NMMOF and d) NMO. O 1 s XPS spectra with various Ar<sup>+</sup> etching depth of the e) NMMOF and f) NMO. F 1 s XPS spectra with various Ar<sup>+</sup> etching depth of the g) NMMOF and h) NMO.</p></span></span></figure></div></section><section id="sec0010"><h3 id="cesectitle0015" class="u-h4 u-margin-m-top u-margin-xs-bottom">3.3. Structural evolution</h3><div class="u-margin-s-bottom"><div id="para0020">The structural evolution process of NMMOF and NMO upon Na<sup>+</sup> extraction and insertion was revealed by <em>in-situ</em> XRD during the initial cycle and second charge process as shown in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig0004" name="bfig0004" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig0004"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 4</span></span></a>a and b. The corresponding refined crystal parameters are concluded in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig0004" name="bfig0004" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig0004"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 4</span></span></a>c and S15. During the initial charge process, the (002) and (004) peaks of NMMOF shift to lower angles, whereas the (112) and (114) peaks shift to higher angles. That is attributed to the extraction of Na<sup>+</sup> from the structure, which leads to the expansion of <em>c</em> axis owing to stronger electrostatic repulsion between adjacent oxygen layers, while the <em>ab</em> plane shrinks resulting from Mn<sup>3+</sup><span> <a href="/topics/materials-science/oxidation-reaction" title="Learn more about oxidation from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">oxidation</a> to Mn</span><sup>4+</sup>. The OP4 phase appears when the voltage reached to 3.5 V and persists until charging is completed, caused by the gliding of [MnO<sub>6</sub><span>] layers under the strong repulsive forces. The structural transition process is similar in NMO, however rather than bi-phase coexistence, it entirely transforms to OP4 phase at fully charged state. Following <a href="/topics/materials-science/sodium-ion" title="Learn more about Na ions from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">Na ions</a><span> insertion, the OP4 phase in NMMOF firstly reverts back to P’2 phase and subsequently evolves into P′′2 phase within a quite narrow voltage range due to the restrained J-T effect. Nevertheless, the NMO electrode undergoes more severe phase transition process when the voltage reaches to 2.2 V, resulting in a distinct two-phase region. In the subsequent charge processes of NMMOF and NMO, the bi-phase state gradually transforms into P'2 phase, followed by the OP4 phase, in accordance with the initial cycle. As can be concluded, NMMOF exhibits a reversible phase transformation from P’2 → P’2 + OP4 → P’2 → P’2 + P”2 →P’2 → P’2 + OP4, while NMO displays more serious structural evolution from P’2 → P’2 + OP4 → OP4 → P’2 + OP4→ P’2 → P’2 + P”2 →P’2 → P’2 + OP4 → OP4. The <a href="/topics/materials-science/lattice-constant" title="Learn more about lattice parameter from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">lattice parameter</a> evolution process and unit-cell volume variation in NMMOF (</span></span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig0004" name="bfig0004" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig0004"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 4</span></span></a>c) fluctuates within a much narrower range compared to NMO (Fig. S15) during the process of Na<sup>+</sup> insertion and extraction, indicating structural robustness against intergranular stress and strain after Mg and F modulation.</div><figure class="figure text-xs" id="fig0004"><span><img src="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S2405829724001302-gr4.jpg" height="408" alt="Fig 4" aria-describedby="cap0004"><ol class="u-margin-s-bottom"><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S2405829724001302-gr4_lrg.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download high-res image (651KB)"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download high-res image (651KB)</span></span></span></a></li><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S2405829724001302-gr4.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download full-size image"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download full-size image</span></span></span></a></li></ol></span><span class="captions text-s"><span id="cap0004"><p id="spara004"><span class="label">Fig. 4</span>. <em>In-situ</em><span> XRD counter mappings for a) NMMOF and b) NMO electrodes during the initial cycle and second charge process. c) The evolution of crystal <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/lattice-parameter" title="Learn more about lattice parameters from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">lattice parameters</a> and unit-cell volume during the initial cycle and second charge process of NMMOF.</span></p></span></span></figure></div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="para0021">From the structure evolution of NMMO in Fig. S16a, the counter mapping is similar to that of NMMOF apart from the complete transition to OP4 phase at fully charged state. The reversible structural change process in NMMO reveals that the Mg dopant effectively restricts the J-T distortion during Mn<sup>4+</sup> reduction. Additionally, the removal of Na<sup>+</sup> in NMOF results in an obvious two-phase region consisting of P’2 phase and OP4 phase (Fig. S16b). This distinction arises from the decreased electrostatic repulsion between the neighboring oxygen layer due to the introduction of F with a lower negative charge and stronger electronegativity, which effectively suppresses shearing of [MnO<sub>6</sub>] layer and lattice collapse. As a consequence, the incorporation of Mg and F dopants in NMMOF synergistically enhance the local crystal framework stability and alleviate the adverse structural evolution during the electrochemical process.</div></section><section id="sec0011"><h3 id="cesectitle0016" class="u-h4 u-margin-m-top u-margin-xs-bottom">3.4. Charge compensation mechanism</h3><div class="u-margin-s-bottom"><div id="para0022">The charge compensation mechanisms of NMMOF and NMO in their charge/discharge states were revealed using <em>ex situ</em> XPS measurements. The Mn 2p spectra in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig0005" name="bfig0005" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig0005"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 5</span></span></a>a and b display splitting peaks, with the two peaks located at 641.5 eV and 643.0 eV attributed to Mn 2p<sub>3/2</sub>, and the two peaks at 653.1 eV and 655.2 eV assigned to Mn 2p<sub>1/2</sub><span>. The additional peak corresponds to Augers of C-F bond and Na-F bond originated from the NMMOF material, as well as the introduction of FEC and <a href="/topics/chemistry/polyvinylidene-fluoride" title="Learn more about PVDF from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">PVDF</a> </span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0052" name="bbib0052" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0052"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[52]</span></span></a>. Upon charging process, the intensity of Mn<sup>4+</sup> becomes stronger, indicating the oxidation of Mn<sup>3+</sup> to Mn<sup>4+</sup> with the peak shift toward higher binding energy. Conversely, during discharging progress with the insertion of Na<sup>+</sup>, the intensity of Mn<sup>3+</sup> increases, suggesting the reduction of Mn<sup>4+</sup>. From the F 1 s spectra (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig0005" name="bfig0005" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig0005"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 5</span></span></a>c), the fluctuation in Na-F bond intensity at various states can be attributed to the Na<sup>+</sup> transportation. As a result, the charge compensation is facilitated by the redox couple of Mn<sup>3+</sup>/ Mn<sup>4+</sup>.</div><figure class="figure text-xs" id="fig0005"><span><img src="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S2405829724001302-gr5.jpg" height="277" alt="Fig 5" aria-describedby="cap0005"><ol class="u-margin-s-bottom"><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S2405829724001302-gr5_lrg.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download high-res image (456KB)"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download high-res image (456KB)</span></span></span></a></li><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S2405829724001302-gr5.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download full-size image"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download full-size image</span></span></span></a></li></ol></span><span class="captions text-s"><span id="cap0005"><p id="spara005"><span class="label">Fig. 5</span>. <em>Ex situ</em> XPS spectra of Mn 2p collected from the pristine, initial charge, and initial discharge states of a) NMMOF and b) NMO. c) F 1 s spectra of NMMOF in the pristine, initial charge, and initial discharge states.</p></span></span></figure></div></section><section id="sec0012"><h3 id="cesectitle0017" class="u-h4 u-margin-m-top u-margin-xs-bottom">3.5. Theoretical calculation</h3><div class="u-margin-s-bottom"><div id="para0023"><span>To identify the local <a href="/topics/chemistry/chemistry" title="Learn more about chemistry from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">chemistry</a> and electronic structures, DFT calculations were carried out </span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0053" name="bbib0053" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0053"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[53]</span></span></a><span>. The optimized structural models used for calculations are displayed in Fig. S17. The band gap of NMMOF is obviously lower than that of NMO from the <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/density-of-states" title="Learn more about density of states from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">density of states</a> (DOS) comparison in </span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig0006" name="bfig0006" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig0006"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 6</span></span></a><span>a and b, exhibiting promoted electronic conductivity and faster charge transfer kinetics. After Mg and F co-doping, the simulated average bond length variation trend of Mn-O bonds and Na-O bonds is consistent with the XRD refinement results. In particular, the Mn-O bonds exhibited increased <a href="/topics/materials-science/mechanical-strength" title="Learn more about strength from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">strength</a> due to their shorter average lengths compared to those of NMO (</span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig0006" name="bfig0006" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig0006"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 6</span></span></a><span>c), which makes them advantageous for preserving structural robustness and integrity. Meanwhile, the <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/weak-interaction" title="Learn more about weaker interaction from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">weaker interaction</a><span> between Na and O in NMMOF benefits in expanding the <a href="/topics/materials-science/sodium" title="Learn more about sodium from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">sodium</a> layer and accelerating Na</span></span><sup>+</sup> diffusion, which is consistent with the experimental results mentioned above. The overlap of electron cloud between Mn and O gets weaker in NMMOF from the discrepancy in partial charge density distribution in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig0006" name="bfig0006" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig0006"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 6</span></span></a><span>d and e, indicating that <a href="/topics/chemistry/electron-localization" title="Learn more about electron localization from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">electron localization</a> occurs among dopants and the neighboring Mn and O with less covalency for the Mn–O bonds compared with NMO (Fig. S18). To further investigate the local electronic structural changes of Mg and F dopants, the electron localization function (ELF) was calculated. The enhanced ionicity between Mn and O resulting from co-doping modulation contributes to a higher redox voltage of NMMOF with increased electronic localization </span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0054" name="bbib0054" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0054"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[54]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0055" name="bbib0055" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0055"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[55]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0056" name="bbib0056" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0056"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[56]</span></span></a>, as revealed by local electronic status alteration shown in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig0006" name="bfig0006" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig0006"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 6</span></span></a><span>f and g. Meanwhile, the ELF results are in accordance with the change of electron density, demonstrating that the electronic <a href="/topics/chemistry/charge-distribution" title="Learn more about charge distribution from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">charge distribution</a> is regulated by the localization of electrons facilitated by Mg and F dopants.</span></div><figure class="figure text-xs" id="fig0006"><span><img src="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S2405829724001302-gr6.jpg" height="541" alt="Fig 6" aria-describedby="cap0006"><ol class="u-margin-s-bottom"><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S2405829724001302-gr6_lrg.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download high-res image (1MB)"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download high-res image (1MB)</span></span></span></a></li><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S2405829724001302-gr6.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download full-size image"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download full-size image</span></span></span></a></li></ol></span><span class="captions text-s"><span id="cap0006"><p id="spara006"><span class="label">Fig. 6</span>. <span>DOS of a) NMMOF and b) NMO. c) The average bond length comparison of NMMOF and NMO. Charge density distribution of d) NMMOF and e) NMO. Slices of <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/density-functional-theory" title="Learn more about DFT from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">DFT</a> calculated </span><a href="/topics/chemistry/electron-localization" title="Learn more about ELF from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">ELF</a> distribution of f) NMMOF and g) NMO.</p></span></span></figure></div></section></section><section id="sec0013"><h2 id="cesectitle0018" class="u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">4. Conclusions</h2><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="para0024">In conclusion, Mg and F co-doped P’2-type cathode materials have been successfully synthesized using a convenient solid-phase method. A combination of various characterization techniques, including <sup>19</sup><span>F ssNMR, XPS, and EDS mapping, demonstrate the Mg and F occupied Mn and O sites, respectively. Both experimental and theoretical analysis show that this synergistic co-doping strategy aids to enhance <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/structural-stability" title="Learn more about structural stability from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">structural stability</a> and sodium storage performance. Specifically, Mg effectively restrains Na</span><sup>+</sup><span>/vacancy rearrangement and J-T effect derived Mn-O bond anisotropic alteration, while F retards structural evolution at high voltage and enhances <a href="/topics/materials-science/electrical-conductivity" title="Learn more about electrical conductivity from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">electrical conductivity</a> with accelerated kinetics. By employing this synergistic co-doping strategy to enhance both structural stability and reversibility simultaneously, the P’2 Na</span><sub>0.64</sub>Mn<sub>0.96</sub>Mg<sub>0.04</sub>O<sub>1.92</sub>F<sub>0.08</sub><span> electrode displays high specific capacity along with extended cycling life and rate capability. This design concept enables the fabrication of novel cathode materials with outstanding performance for <a href="/topics/chemistry/sodium-ion-battery" title="Learn more about SIBs from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">SIBs</a>.</span></div></section><section id="sec0013a"><h2 id="cesectitle0018a" class="u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">CRediT authorship contribution statement</h2><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="para0024a"><strong>Xuchun Chen:</strong> Data curation, Methodology, Writing – original draft. <strong>Guangliang Lin:</strong> Methodology, Software. <strong>Pei Liu:</strong> Investigation, Writing – review &amp; editing. <strong>Zhiqin Sun:</strong> Methodology, Writing – review &amp; editing. <strong>Yuchang Si:</strong> Supervision, Writing – review &amp; editing. <strong>Qinglun Wang:</strong> Supervision, Writing – review &amp; editing. <strong>Lifang Jiao:</strong> Conceptualization, Funding acquisition, Project administration, Supervision, Writing – review &amp; editing.</div></section></div><section id="coi0001"><h2 id="cesectitle0020" class="u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">Declaration of competing interest</h2><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="para0027">The authors declare no conflict of interest.</div></section><section id="ack0001"><h2 id="cesectitle0019" class="u-h4 u-margin-l-top class="reference" id="sbref0056"><div class="contribution"><div class="authors u-font-sans">X. Wang, X. Fan, X. Yu, S. Bak, Z. Shadike, I. Waluyo, A. Hunt, S.D. Senanayake, H. Li, L. Chen, C. Wang, R. Xiao, E. Hu, X.Q. Yang</div><div id="ref-id-sbref0056" class="title text-m">The role of electron localization in covalency and electrochemical properties of lithium-ion battery cathode materials</div></div><div class="host u-font-sans">Adv. Funct. Mater., 31 (2020), Article 2001633</div><div class="ReferenceLinks u-font-sans"><a class="anchor link anchor-primary" href="https://scholar.google.com/scholar_lookup?title=The%20role%20of%20electron%20localization%20in%20covalency%20and%20electrochemical%20properties%20of%20lithium-ion%20battery%20cathode%20materials&amp;publication_year=2020&amp;author=X.%20Wang&amp;author=X.%20Fan&amp;author=X.%20Yu&amp;author=S.%20Bak&amp;author=Z.%20Shadike&amp;author=I.%20Waluyo&amp;author=A.%20Hunt&amp;author=S.D.%20Senanayake&amp;author=H.%20Li&amp;author=L.%20Chen&amp;author=C.%20Wang&amp;author=R.%20Xiao&amp;author=E.%20Hu&amp;author=X.Q.%20Yang"
